III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 8/8/23 at 10am, Supervisor allegedly punched Youth H in the
chest after Youth H assaulted him. There were no immediate
visible injuries.
Investigation DCWL received this allegation reported by Complainant, also the
facility nurse, on 8/8/23, the same day the incident occurred.
I notified Youth H’s foster care worker via email and collaborated
with Government Worker 1 via phone.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
On 8/10/23, I arrived at the facility accompanied by Government
Worker 1 and viewed video footage of the incident.
Video of Pod A dayroom
9:24:39 – 09:24:46 - Youth H pulls the door down from locked
metal grievance box attempting to break it off. Supervisors 1, 2
and Facility Manager approach him and Youth H runs away from
them toward the youth bedrooms.
9:24:47 – 9:25:01 - Supervisor 1 moves with Youth H to the wall
and attempts a single person Primary Restraint Technique (PRT)
for four seconds. Youth H slides down the wall to the floor.
Supervisor 2, Facility Manager and Supervisor 1 pull the youth
back to a standing position. Facility Manager opens a nearby
bedroom door. Youth H is ushered into the room.
09:25:02 – 09:27:24 - Supervisors 1, 2 and Facility Manager are
inside the room or at the room entrance. The open door blocks
the view of the entrance to the room. Supervisor 2 leaves the
room and returns three times.
2

09:27:25 – 09:29:25 Facility Manager and Supervisor 2 are
bringing tissue back and forth to the room.
9:29:26 Youth H exits on his own and walks to his room.
I asked Operations Manager (who showed us the video) why
destroying a grievance box warranted restraint. He said it’s parts
can cause serious harm to self and can be used as a weapon
against others.
An incident report authored by Facility Manager at 9:26am on
8/8/23 indicated the following:
“While on Pod A, Youth H became upset over not being able to sit
in seven chairs stacked on the pod. Supervisor 1 attempted to
verbally de-escalate the situation but was unsuccessful. Youth H
started punching the grievance box. Supervisors 1 and 2
intervened; Youth H began to punch Supervisor 1 in the arm and
face. He was escorted to his room and placed on a time-out; while
being counseled inside of his room, Youth H continued to punch,
stab with a toothbrush and bite Supervisor 1. He calmed down
after five minutes and regained self-control. Youth H was then
counseled by Facility Manager on his behaviors. Youth H was by
the facility nurse.”
I interviewed Youth H jointly with Government Worker 1 on
8/10/23. I observed his chest area and there were no visible
marks or bruises. Youth H said he tore the door off the grievance
box on 8/8/23 and Supervisor 1 physically restrained him against
the wall. Staff moved him into a bedroom, Youth H grabbed a
toothbrush, and stabbed Supervisor in his leg. “Supervisor 1
punched me once in the chest and held me by my head and chest
on someone’s bed. Supervisor 2 and Facility Manager were there
looking right at us. I couldn’t breathe in or out.” Supervisor 2 and
Facility Manager had him seen by the nurse. “They moved
Supervisor 1 to Calumet.”
After the incident, Youth H was assessed by the facility nurse and
required no medical treatment. A chest x-ray of Youth H was
requested by Government Worker 1 and completed on 8/10/23
showing no abnormalities.
I interviewed Facility Manager jointly with Government Worker 1.
He has worked at the facility for 15 years. Facility Manager said
he saw Youth H punching the metal grievance box and tried to
verbally de-escalate him. “Youth H tried to tear the box off the
3

wall. Supervisor 1 and 2 intervened to prevent self-harm. Youth
H ran and they ran after him. They wanted to place him in a PRT.
Youth H resisted and punched and bit Supervisor 1. Youth H
dropped to the ground. They lifted him and got him into room 7.”
Inside the room, “Youth H kept punching Supervisor 1 and tried to
stab him. Supervisor 1 was standing over him trying to stop blows
and talking to him. After five minutes Youth H stopped. His nose
bled from working himself up. We got paper towel for his nose.…I
was there the whole time. I didn’t see Supervisor 1 punch him.”
Inside of the room, Facility Manager said Youth H was on his
knees on the bed facing Supervisor 1. He said Youth H was not
lying on the bed and Supervisor 1 did not hold him down on the
bed. Overall Facility Manager felt the situation had a “good
outcome” because seclusion was avoided.
I interviewed Supervisor 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. He
has worked at the facility for six years. When Supervisor 2 arrived
at the pod, he said Youth H was irritated. “He was destroying the
grievance box…We know youths can harm themselves with that.
I’ve seen people get hit with a grievance box. It’s dangerous.”
When Supervisor 1 attempted to stop Youth H, he said Youth H
punched and tried to bite Supervisor 1. “We tried to hold Youth H.
He was still trying to hit Supervisor 1.”
From the doorway to the room, Supervisor 2 said he saw Youth H
stand on the bed and slide down the wall. “Supervisor 1 became
the ‘target’ and probably should have left. Supervisor 1 stood by
the bed and held Youth H’s arms to stop him from punching.”
Afterward, “Youth H mentioned he got punched, but I did not see
Supervisor 1 punch him…I did not see any toothbrush.”
I interviewed Supervisor 1 jointly with Government Worker 1. He
has worked at the facility for 10 years and is a Handle with Care
Trainer. Supervisor 1 has no disciplinary write-ups in his
personnel file.
Supervisor 1 said he was on the pod “doing rounds” when he saw
Youth H rocking on a stack of 7-8 chairs. “I tried to redirect
verbally. I have a rapport with Youth H.” Youth H got off the
chairs and Supervisor 1 removed them. “Youth H started kicking
walls. I left and called Facility Manager. He and Supervisor 2
came. Youth H hit the grievance box, walked away, returned, and
tried to tear it off the wall. He went toward the wall. I told Facility
Manager to open a room. We went in and I tried to get him calm.
4

He was throwing punches and I’m blocking.” Supervisor 1 denied
hitting Youth H in his chest or holding him down on the bed.
I asked Supervisor 1 why he stayed inside the room with Youth H
rather than exit the room. He said Youth H was hitting him but not
hurting him. Supervisor 1 felt confident he could de-escalate the
youth and said he finds private spaces where youths can “be
themselves” away from others more conducive to 1:1 counseling.
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis To protect Youth H and others from physical injury in response to
Youth H tearing or attempting to tear a metal grievance box off the
wall, Supervisor 1 attempted a single-person Primary Restraint
(wall) Technique but was unsuccessful. The incident report, video
footage, staff interviews and medical reports do not support the
allegation that Supervisor 1 hit or punched Youth H.
CONSULTATION
The facility has experienced issues as a result of youths tearing
metal grievance boxes off the wall and cutting themselves and/or
using the grievance box or door as a weapon. I advised the
facility to consider implementing a safer method for youths to
submit written grievances.
As Supervisor 2 noted, Supervisor 1 became Youth H’s target.
The best defense against blows from a youth is to remove oneself
from the area if possible or switch out with a different staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
